During the late operations of the war against Licinius, he had sufficient op- portunity to contemplate, both as a soldier and as a statesman, the incomparable position of Byzantium3 and to observe how strongly it was guar-ded by nature against an hostile attack, whilst it was acces- fible on every side to the benefits of commercial intercourse. Many ages before Constantine, one of the most judicious historians of an— tiquity ¹ had described the advantages of a situation, from whence a feeble colony of Greeks derived the command of the sea, and the honours of a flourissiing and independent republic ².

If we survey Byzantium in the extent which it acquired with the august name of Constantinople, the figure of the imperial city may be represented under that of an unequal triangle. The obtuse point, which advances towards the east and the ssmres of Asia, meets and repels the waves of the Thracian Bosphorus.
